thread.title: Dubai freezone companies get permit to bid for state tenders
thread.title_full: Dubai freezone companies get permit to bid for state tenders

author: Pramod Kumar
title: Dubai freezone companies get permit to bid for state tenders
text:
Dubai freezone companies get permit to bid for state tenders
Dubai has introduced a permit allowing freezone companies to operate on the mainland and bid for government tenders and contracts.
The Free Zone Mainland Operating Permit has been launched by the Dubai Business Registration and Licensing Corporation under the Department of Economy and Tourism, in partnership with the emirate’s Free Zone Council.
The permit enables freezone companies to participate in non-regulated sectors such as technology, consultancy, design, professional services and trading. It costs AED5,000 ($1,361) for six months and is renewable at the end of that period.
Businesses will be subject to a 9 percent corporate tax and must maintain separate financial records in line with Federal Tax Authority regulations. They are allowed to deploy their existing staff for mainland operations without hiring new employees.
The initiative is expected to boost cross-jurisdictional business by 15 to 20 percent in its first year, the Department of Economy and Tourism said. This will benefit more than 10,000 active free zone companies, who will gain access to large government contracts previously limited to mainland-licensed entities.
Further reading:
In August the Dubai government said its economy increased 4 percent year on year to AED120 billion ($33 billion) in the first quarter of 2025, driven by strong public-private partnerships.
The government has set expenditure at over AED86 billion, with revenues expected at AED98 billion for 2025.
